Award.AwardTitle: TWC: Small: Cross-Application and Cross-Platform Tracking of Web Users: Techniques and Countermeasures

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
There are many applications in business and end-user applications where user tracking is part of the core functionality or feature set. However, user tracking can intrude on user privacy and even may lead to online crimes. Recent research has shown that tracking companies have started using advanced web tracking techniques that are more subtle and less transparent than traditional online tracking. The ever increasing adoption of mobile devices further exacerbates the tracking problem since these mobile devices are saturated with personal information while the details of mobile-specific tracking techniques are largely unknown.

The project seeks a deeper understanding of the existing and potential technical capabilities and limitations of tracking, and the trade-offs between tracking and privacy. The project will conduct a systematic study of techniques and technologies that are used for tracking web users, starting with new variations of traditional tracking methods and proceeding to advanced and stealthy users and device fingerprinting. The research will involve both in-depth analysis and large-scale measurement studies. The gained knowledge will inform security and privacy research communities of the technical capabilities and limits posed by the next generation of user tracking on mobile devices, paying particular attention to the under-researched area of stateless tracking.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In this project, we aimed to understand, measure, and propose defenses against unwanted online tracking. Unwanted online tracking sacrifices user privacy to construct ever-more accurate profiles of users, based on the websites that they browse, in order to target them with more ads. Our goal was to understand how online tracking has evolved over time, how trackers use and abuse modern browser features (in both desktop and mobile devices) for tracking purposes, and propose defenses against the identified tracking practices.


For this project, we designed, developed, and evaluated a large number of systems to quantify tracking activity on the web and investigated the browser features that tracking companies can abuse, next to the ones that were already well known. Among other results, we discovered that it is possible to identify the browser extensions that users install and use these extensions to both infer sensitive information about users, as well as re-identify them in future visits. Similarly, we showed that a large fraction of websites and browser extensions are not carefully handling user data which results in accidental leaks of Personally Identifiable Information to third parties. On the mobile-device front, we discovered that mobile browsers lag behind their desktop counterparts by supporting less security and privacy mechanisms thereby increasing the risk of users who browse the web from their mobile devices. To defend against unwanted tracking, we proposed and made available to the public (via open-source repositories) a number of defense mechanisms (in the form of browser extensions and modifications to open-source browsers) that warn users about websites with poor privacy practices and protect user data when that is entered into websites. We do this by either limiting the reach of third parties or by confusing them about the true interests of tracked users.


Beyond the aforementioned research, this project allowed graduate students (at PhD and MS levels) to develop expertise in crawler construction, network protocols, extension development, and big-data analytics in addition to experimenting with virtualization on public cloud providers. All of these skills are valuable for their future careers, for the advancement of national prosperity, and for securing the national defense. We incorporated the findings of this project in the undergraduate and graduate security courses taught at our respective institutions, taken by hundreds of students on a yearly basis.
